prior_works.title: Maximum Likelihood Estimation of Observer Error-Rates Using the EM Algorithm
prior_works.authors: A. P. Dawid, A. M. Skene
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced the multi-annotator confusion-matrix framework and EM estimation, the backbone that this paper extends to an instance-dependent setting and exploits for crowd-based identifiability.

prior_works.title: Learning From Crowds
prior_works.authors: V. C. Raykar, S. Yu, L. H. Zhao, G. H. Valadez, C. Florin, L. Bogoni, L. Moy
prior_works.role: Methodological precursor linking annotator confusions with a predictive model
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed how to jointly learn a classifier and annotator reliabilities from multiple labels; the present work builds on this multi-annotator paradigm and adds identifiability guarantees under instance-dependent outliers.

prior_works.title: Spectral Methods meet EM: A Provably Optimal Algorithm for Crowdsourcing
prior_works.authors: Y. Zhang, X. Chen, D. Zhou, M. I. Jordan
prior_works.role: Provable identifiability/estimation of worker confusion in multiclass crowds
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established that cross-annotator moment structure enables identification of latent confusion matrices; the new paper leverages this "crowd wisdom" idea to recover models even when instance-dependent outliers are present.

prior_works.title: Learning with Noisy Labels
prior_works.authors: N. Natarajan, I. S. Dhillon, P. Ravikumar, A. Tewari
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Cast noisy-label learning via a class-conditional transition matrix and unbiased risk correction; the current work relaxes the instance-invariant assumption and studies identifiability when transitions vary (creating outliers).

prior_works.title: Making Deep Neural Networks Robust to Label Noise: A Loss Correction Approach
prior_works.authors: G. Patrini, A. Rozza, A. K. Menon, R. Nock, L. Qu
prior_works.role: Practical loss-correction via a global confusion/transition matrix
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Popularized confusion-matrix-based correction but assumes an instance-invariant matrix; the new paper explains why that is insufficient with instance-dependent deviations and shows how multiple annotators restore identifiability.

prior_works.title: Part-Dependent Label Noise: Towards Instance-Dependent Label Noise
prior_works.authors: X. Xia, T. Liu, N. Liu, B. Han, G. Niu, M. Sugiyama
prior_works.role: Formalization of instance-dependent label noise and its challenges
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Highlighted the difficulty of learning under instance-dependent noise from singly-labeled data; the present work addresses this by proving that single annotators are insufficient and leveraging multiple annotators for identification.

prior_works.title: Tensor Decompositions for Learning Latent Variable Models
prior_works.authors: A. Anandkumar, R. Ge, D. Hsu, S. M. Kakade, M. Telgarsky
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the multi-view identifiability perspective that underpins using cross-annotator correlations (higher-order moments) to recover latent structures—an approach mirrored in using crowd wisdom for identifiability with outliers.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s key contribution is an identifiability theory for confusion-matrix–based noisy-label learning when confusion matrices vary across instances, yielding occasional outliers. This advances beyond the standard class-conditional (instance-invariant) transition-matrix assumption popularized in noisy-label learning and loss-correction methods. Natarajan et al. and Patrini et al. formalized and operationalized the transition-matrix view, but their guarantees hinge on a fixed matrix, leaving identifiability open when noise is instance dependent. Xia et al. articulated the practical and theoretical difficulties of instance-dependent label noise—particularly acute when each example has only a single noisy label—foreshadowing the impossibility the present work makes explicit.

The resolution draws on the crowdsourcing lineage. Dawid and Skene introduced the annotator confusion-matrix model and EM estimation, establishing the core statistical structure for multi-annotator data. Raykar et al. coupled this with a predictive model, showing the feasibility of jointly inferring ground truth and annotator reliabilities. Modern provable approaches, exemplified by Zhang et al., reveal that cross-annotator moment structure ("crowd wisdom") can identify per-worker confusion matrices in multiclass settings. This multi-view identifiability perspective is broadly grounded in tensor/moment methods (Anandkumar et al.), which justify recovering latent parameters from higher-order correlations. The present paper leverages these insights to show that, while single-annotator labels are fundamentally insufficient to detect instance-dependent outliers, multiple annotators provide the redundancy needed to identify the ground-truth classifier and the underlying confusion mechanisms, thereby extending confusion-matrix methods to a more realistic, instance-dependent regime.
